docs.text:
Welcome to MkDocs


For full documentation visit 
mkdocs.org
.


Commands




mkdocs new [dir-name]
 - Create a new project.


mkdocs serve
 - Start the live-reloading docs server.


mkdocs build
 - Build the documentation site.


mkdocs help
 - Print this help message.




Project layout


mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.text:
Install FreeBSD on Dell T5000


Introduction


Two months ago, I bought a Dell Precision T5500 Workstation on ebay.
For less than two hundred euros, I had a Xeon hexa core, twelve giga byte of RAM, a 250 gb hard drive and a Nvidia Quattro graphic cards.
I added to it a PCI-e SATAIII card, two SSD ( one of 128 GB and another of 250 Gb), one hard drive of 1 TB, a wifi pci card, and I replaced the graphic card with an Nvidia GeForce GT 710.
Now it's time to install and configure FreeBSD on it.




Note




For info, big thank you to Olivier Cochard-Labbé and Allison Nicole Reid for all good informations I found on their websites
http://olivier.cochard.me/bidouillage/installation-et-configuration-de-freebsd-comme-poste-de-travail
https://cooltrainer.org/a-freebsd-desktop-howto/


Installation


Download FreeBSD


I downloaded FreeBSD 11.1 on mirror at:

[TODO] Write the download link here


I used dd to put the image on USB stick


dd if=**imagedisk** of=/dev/sdc bs=1024





Install FreeBSD 11.1


I'll don't describe here how to install FreeBSD.
Read the official doc to do it.


Configuration


Packages


Frist, I need to install sudo and add my user in priviliged list


pkg install -y sudo





And add my fralix user


visudo

######################
%fralix ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL
######################





I installed all theses packages before to start to configure the system:


bash 
 tmux


pkg install -y bash tmux





Xorg


pkg install -y xorg





Fonts


pkg install -y chinese/arphicttf chinese/font-std hebrew/culmus hebrew/elmar-fonts japanese/font-ipa japanese/font-ipa-uigothic japanese/font-ipaex japanese/font-kochi japanese/font-migmix japanese/font-migu japanese/font-mona-ipa japanese/font-motoya-al japanese/font-mplus-ipa japanese/font-sazanami japanese/font-shinonome japanese/font-takao japanese/font-ume japanese/font-vlgothic x11-fonts/hanazono-fonts-ttf japanese/font-mikachan korean/aleefonts-ttf korean/nanumfonts-ttf korean/unfonts-core x11-fonts/anonymous-pro x11-fonts/artwiz-aleczapka x11-fonts/dejavu x11-fonts/inconsolata-ttf x11-fonts/terminus-font x11-fonts/cantarell-fonts x11-fonts/droid-fonts-ttf x11-fonts/doulos x11-fonts/ubuntu-font x11-fonts/isabella x11-fonts/ecofont x11-fonts/junicode x11-fonts/khmeros x11-fonts/padauk x11-fonts/stix-fonts x11-fonts/charis x11-fonts/urwfonts-ttf russian/koi8r-ps x11-fonts/geminifonts x11-fonts/cyr-rfx x11-fonts/paratype x11-fonts/gentium-plus urwfonts bitstream-vera webfonts





Others


pkg install -y devcpu-data ca_root_nss xscreensaver git firefox firefox-i18n chromium libreoffice cups cups-filters gnome3 dia hexchat mumble vlc thunderbird automount  fusefs-ntfs gimp password-store





Locales


Put this two lines into the default section in 
/etc/login.conf
:


**
:charset=UTF-8:\
:lang=en_US.UTF-8:\
**


Rebuild the login database:


sudo cap_mkdb /etc/login.conf





Modify 
/etc/profile


vi /etc/profile

LANG=en_US.UTF-8;   export LANG
CHARSET=UTF-8;  export CHARSET





Set bash at default shell for fralix account


sudo chsh -s /usr/local/bin/bash fralix





Configure /etc/sysctl.conf


sudo cat 
 /etc/sysctl.conf 
EOF
kern.vt.enable_bell=0
hw.syscons.bell=0
kern.ipc.shmmax=67108864
kern.ipc.shmall=32768
kern.sched.preempt_thresh=224
kern.maxfiles=200000
hw.syscons.bell=0
kern.ipc.shm_allow_removed=1
hw.snd.default_unit=0
EOF





Configure /boot/loader.conf


sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf autoboot_delay=2
sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf kern.ipc.shmseg=1024
sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf kern.ipc.shmmni=1024
sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf kern.maxproc=100000
sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf coretemp_load=
YES

sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf tmpfs_load=
YES

sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf aio_load=
YES

sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf snd_driver_load=
YES

sudo sysrc -f /boot/loader.conf fusefs_load=
YES






Configure /etc/rc.conf


sudo sysrc ntpd_sync_on_start=yes
sudo sysrc kld_list+=smbus
sudo sysrc microcode_update_enable=YES
sudo sysrc dbus_enable=YES
sudo sysrc hald_enable=YES
sudo sysrc cupsd_enable=YES
sudo sysrc gdm_enable=
YES

sudo sysrc gnome_enable=
YES

sudo sysrc fusefs_enable=YES
sudo sysrc autofs_enable=YES
sudo sysrc automount_enable=YES
sudo sysrc automountd_enable=YES
sudo sysrc autounmountd_enable=YES





Configure /procfs


sudo vi /etc/fstab

proc           /proc       procfs  rw  0   0





Configure automount


sudo sed -i 
 -e 
s/#\/media/\/media/
 /etc/auto_master

sudo cat 
/etc/devd.conf 
EOF
# Discard autofs caches, useful for the -media special map.
notify 100 {
        match 
system
 
GEOM
;
        match 
subsystem
 
DEV
;
        action 
/usr/sbin/automount -c
;
};
EOF





Xorg


Download the latest Nvidia driver at http://www.nvidia.com and put the archive NVIDIA-FreeBSD-x86_64-384.59.tar.gz to 
/var/tmp


Extract the archive and compile/install the nvidia xorg driver


cd /var/tmp
tar -zxf NVIDIA-FreeBSD-x86_64-384.59.tar.gz
cd NVIDIA-FreeBSD-x86_64-384.59
sudo make install -j4





Configure xorg:


sudo cat 
 /usr/local/etc/X11/xorg.conf.d/20-video.conf 
EOF

Section 
Device


        Identifier 
NVIDIA Card


        VendorName 
NVIDIA Corporation


        Driver 
nvidia


EndSection

Section 
Module

        Load           
freetype

        Load           
bitmap

        Load           
type1

        Load           
glx

EndSection


EOF

docs.text:
Introduction


I need to had a hard drive on my workstation.
I want encrypt data and add read 
 write cache.


Operation


SSD


I'll create two partitions:




One for the write cache (log0)


One for the read cache (cache0)




gpart add -t freebsd-zfs -b 2048 -a 4k -l log0 -s 32G ada0
gpart add -t freebsd-zfs -a 4k -l cache0 ada0





Look how it is:


gpart show /dev/ada0
=
       40  234441568  ada0  GPT  (112G)
         40       2008        - free -  (1.0M)
       2048   67108864     1  freebsd-zfs  (32G)
   67110912  167330688     2  freebsd-zfs  (80G)
  234441600          8        - free -  (4.0K)





Zpool on the hard drive


gpart create -s gpt ada3
gpart add -t freebsd-zfs -l volume-zdata0 ada3
geli init -l 256 /dev/gpt/volume-zdata0
geli attach /dev/gpt/volume-zdata0
zpool create -m none zdata0 /dev/gpt/volume-zdata0.eli





Now we'll add write and read cache


zpool add zdata0 log gpt/log0
zpool add zdata0 cache gpt/cache0





Quand le sys reboot, il faut redonner la passphrase de chiffrement et faire un zpool import


geli attach /dev/gpt/volume-zdata0
zpool import
zfs mount
docs.title: Add Hard Drive with cache on SSD

docs.text:
Install GrayLog server for lab testing


Intro


This is an installation guide of Graylog for Lab env.
Do not use this documentation for production use !


Installation


Create lxc container on lxc-host-04


Creation


ssh salt.int.cozycloud.cc
cd ~/dev/nico/proxmox-deploy
./deploy-lxc-on-host.sh lxc-host-04.cozycloud.cc graylog-00-dev 10.255.100.52 salt-dev





Reinstall it to condfigure capping


By default, script on salt server doesn't configurer lxc capping.
Connect to lxc-host-04, backup ssh and salt conf of the graylog container, destroy the container, reinstall it with capping, restore ssh and salt conf.


ssh lxc-host-04.int.cozycloud.cc
lxc-stop -n graylog-00-dev
mount /dev/lxc/graylog-00-dev /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
tar zcfp graylog-00-dev.tgz /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/etc/{salt,ssh}
umount /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
lxc-destroy -n graylog-00-dev 
create-lxc-guest -T -p -m 16G -w 8G -s 200G -n graylog-00-dev -d int.cozycloud.cc -P apt.int.cozycloud.cc -i 10.255.100.52 -S salt-dev.int.cozycloud.cc -M graylog-00-dev.int.cozycloud.cc
mount /dev/lxc/graylog-00-dev /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
cd /
tar -zxf ~/graylog-00-dev.tgz
umount /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
lxc-start -n graylog-00-dev





Install zabbix agent


For this lab, we'll need to have informations about how much graylog and ELK will consume.


ssh salt-dev.int.cozycloud.cc
cd /srv/pillar/hosts/int_cozycloud.cc
vi graylog-00-dev.sls

root@salt-dev:/srv/pillar/hosts/int_cozycloud_cc# cat graylog-00-dev.sls 
roles:
  - zabbix.agent

git add graylog-00-dev.sls
salt --state-output=changes 
graylog-00*
 state.highstate





Backports and some pkgs


We'll need backports to deploy all softwares


ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
echo 
deb http://ftp.debian.org/debian jessie-backports main
 
 /etc/apt/sources.list.d/backports.list
apt-get update
apt-get upgrade
apt install -y ca-certificates-java apt-transport-https uuid-runtime pwgen wget
apt-get install -t jessie-backports openjdk-8-jdk
update-java-alternatives --set java-1.8.0-openjdk-amd64





Graylog Installation


First, we need to install and configure mongodb serveur and ElasticSearch.
For this dev env, we'll not install them in cluster mode.


MongoDB


Install


ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
apt-get install -y mongodb-server





Elasticsearch


Install


ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
wget -qO - https://artifacts.elastic.co/GPG-KEY-elasticsearch | apt-key add -
echo 
deb https://artifacts.elastic.co/packages/5.x/apt stable main
 | tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list.d/elastic-5.x.list
apt update 
 apt install elasticsearch





Configuration


Make sure to modify the Elasticsearch configuration file (/etc/elasticsearch/elasticsearch.yml) and set the cluster name to graylog additionally you need to uncomment (remove the # as first character) the line:


cluster.name: graylog





By default, ElasticSearch is configured to use 2G of Ram. We'll add 6 Go.


vi /etc/elasticsearch/jvm.options
-Xms8g
-Xmx8g





Launch elasticsearch


After you have modified the configuration, you can start Elasticsearch:


systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl enable elasticsearch.service
systemctl restart elasticsearch.service





Graylog


Install


ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
wget https://packages.graylog2.org/repo/packages/graylog-2.3-repository_latest.deb
dpkg -i graylog-2.3-repository_latest.deb
apt update 
 apt install graylog-server





Configuration


We'll need to edit /etc/graylog/server/server.conf
But before, generate two passwords with:


pwgen -N 1 -s 96
Cj6kY5vzNtog1sEyhT1ezRBGardpLWMggSsQLS9gdATUwCQORkQrgsaGMRmzJHaquuPx8dlDD9UTQP7cmjMINjdqQ8bNMDQq
and

echo -n cozy42! | sha256sum
e83651034b3887b31ec01d714cff32585784589b5e544b4b58d15e0f97dec87e

vi /etc/graylog/server/server.conf

password_secret = Cj6kY5vzNtog1sEyhT1ezRBGardpLWMggSsQLS9gdATUwCQORkQrgsaGMRmzJHaquuPx8dlDD9UTQP7cmjMINjdqQ8bNMDQq
root_password_sha2 = e83651034b3887b31ec01d714cff32585784589b5e544b4b58d15e0f97dec87e
rest_listen_uri = http://0.0.0.0:9110/api/
rest_transport_uri = http://10.255.100.52:9110/api/
rest_enable_cors = true
web_enable = true
web_listen_uri = http://127.0.0.1:9000/
web_enable_cors = true





Launch graylog


systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl enable graylog-server.service
systemctl start graylog-server.service





Apache


apt install -y apache2
cd /etc/apache2/mods-enabled
ln -s ../mods-available/proxy.conf ./
ln -s ../mods-available/proxy.load ./
ln -s ../mods-available/headers.load ./
ln -s ../mods-available/proxy_http.load ./

cd /etc/apache2/sites-enabled
vi 000-default.conf

VirtualHost *:8080

    ServerAdmin root@localhost
        ServerName graylog-00-dev.int.cozycloud.cc
        ProxyRequests off
    
Proxy *

                Order deny,allow
                Deny from all
                allow from all
        
/Proxy

        ProxyPreserveHost on
        ProxyPass /api/ http://127.0.0.1:9110/api/
        ProxyPassReverse /api/ http://127.0.0.1:9110/api/

        RequestHeader set X-Graylog-Server-URL 
http://localhost:8080/api/

        ProxyPass / http://127.0.0.1:9000/ nocanon
        ProxyPassReverse  /  http://127.0.0.1:9000/
        AllowEncodedSlashes NoDecode

/VirtualHost






Connect to web interface


ssh -L 9000:10.255.100.52:9000 graylog-00-dev.int.cozycloud.cc





Rsyslog client configuration


vi /etc/rsyslog.d/client.conf


*.* @@graylog-00-dev.int.cozycloud.cc:1520;RSYSLOG_SyslogProtocol23Format
docs.title: Install graylog server
Install GrayLog server for lab testing

docs.text:
This is an installation guide of Graylog for Lab env.
Do not use this documentation for production use !
docs.title: Intro

docs.text:
ssh salt.int.cozycloud.cc
cd ~/dev/nico/proxmox-deploy
./deploy-lxc-on-host.sh lxc-host-04.cozycloud.cc graylog-00-dev 10.255.100.52 salt-dev
docs.title: Creation

docs.text:
By default, script on salt server doesn't configurer lxc capping.
Connect to lxc-host-04, backup ssh and salt conf of the graylog container, destroy the container, reinstall it with capping, restore ssh and salt conf.  ssh lxc-host-04.int.cozycloud.cc
lxc-stop -n graylog-00-dev
mount /dev/lxc/graylog-00-dev /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
tar zcfp graylog-00-dev.tgz /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/etc/{salt,ssh}
umount /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
lxc-destroy -n graylog-00-dev 
create-lxc-guest -T -p -m 16G -w 8G -s 200G -n graylog-00-dev -d int.cozycloud.cc -P apt.int.cozycloud.cc -i 10.255.100.52 -S salt-dev.int.cozycloud.cc -M graylog-00-dev.int.cozycloud.cc
mount /dev/lxc/graylog-00-dev /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
cd /
tar -zxf ~/graylog-00-dev.tgz
umount /var/lib/lxc/graylog-00-dev/rootfs/
lxc-start -n graylog-00-dev
docs.title: Reinstall it to condfigure capping

docs.text:
For this lab, we'll need to have informations about how much graylog and ELK will consume.  ssh salt-dev.int.cozycloud.cc
cd /srv/pillar/hosts/int_cozycloud.cc
vi graylog-00-dev.sls

root@salt-dev:/srv/pillar/hosts/int_cozycloud_cc# cat graylog-00-dev.sls 
roles:
  - zabbix.agent

git add graylog-00-dev.sls
salt --state-output=changes  graylog-00*  state.highstate
docs.title: Install zabbix agent

docs.text:
We'll need backports to deploy all softwares  ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
echo  deb http://ftp.debian.org/debian jessie-backports main    /etc/apt/sources.list.d/backports.list
apt-get update
apt-get upgrade
apt install -y ca-certificates-java apt-transport-https uuid-runtime pwgen wget
apt-get install -t jessie-backports openjdk-8-jdk
update-java-alternatives --set java-1.8.0-openjdk-amd64
docs.title: Backports and some pkgs

docs.text:
First, we need to install and configure mongodb serveur and ElasticSearch.
For this dev env, we'll not install them in cluster mode.
docs.title: Graylog Installation

docs.text:
ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
apt-get install -y mongodb-server
docs.title: Install

docs.text:
ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
wget -qO - https://artifacts.elastic.co/GPG-KEY-elasticsearch | apt-key add -
echo  deb https://artifacts.elastic.co/packages/5.x/apt stable main  | tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list.d/elastic-5.x.list
apt update   apt install elasticsearch
docs.title: Install

docs.text:
Make sure to modify the Elasticsearch configuration file (/etc/elasticsearch/elasticsearch.yml) and set the cluster name to graylog additionally you need to uncomment (remove the # as first character) the line:  cluster.name: graylog  By default, ElasticSearch is configured to use 2G of Ram. We'll add 6 Go.  vi /etc/elasticsearch/jvm.options
-Xms8g
-Xmx8g
docs.title: Configuration

docs.text:
After you have modified the configuration, you can start Elasticsearch:  systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl enable elasticsearch.service
systemctl restart elasticsearch.service
docs.title: Launch elasticsearch

docs.text:
ssh graylog-00-dev.int.cozycoud.cc
wget https://packages.graylog2.org/repo/packages/graylog-2.3-repository_latest.deb
dpkg -i graylog-2.3-repository_latest.deb
apt update   apt install graylog-server
docs.title: Install
